notes:
1. Definition

In one-dimensional flow, it is assumed that the flow parameters (such as velocity, pressure, and density) are constant at any given cross-section perpendicular to the main flow direction, and they only vary along the direction of flow. This is a simplification used for analyzing flow in pipes and channels where the primary motion is along the length of the conduit.

2. Flow Classification

  • Steady vs. Unsteady Flow: In steady flow, the fluid properties at any point in the system do not change with time. In unsteady flow, they do.
  • Uniform vs. Non-uniform Flow: In uniform flow, the velocity vector is identical at every point in the flow field at a given instant. This occurs in long, straight sections of pipe with a constant diameter. In non-uniform flow, the velocity changes from point to point (e.g., in a pipe bend or contraction).
  • Laminar vs. Turbulent Flow: Determined by the Reynolds number ($Re$). Laminar flow is smooth and orderly, while turbulent flow is chaotic and characterized by eddies.

solvedExamples.question: Flow in which the velocity at any given point does not vary with time is called:
solvedExamples.explanation: Steady flow is defined as a flow where the properties (velocity, pressure, density) at any single point in the fluid do not change over time. An example is the constant flow of water through a pipe at a constant rate.
